answers.B: Tell the officer what item you need to locate and wait for verbal permission before reaching.

question: If you must walk on the road because no sidewalk is available, where should you walk according to state driving laws?

question: Under what conditions may you make a left turn on a red light in Minnesota?

correct_answer: Move it away from the main, traveled portion of the road
why_correct: State driving laws require that vehicles left on state highways or freeways be moved away from the main, traveled portion of the roadway.

why_incorrect.A: Hazard lights do not replace the requirement to move the vehicle off the traveled portion.
why_incorrect.C: Parking in the median is not an acceptable alternative and is unsafe.
why_incorrect.D: There is no short-time exception that allows you to leave a vehicle in a traffic lane.

question: If main-line traffic is moving at 10 mph, what is the fastest an authorized bus may travel on the shoulder?

answers.A: 25 mph
answers.B: 35 mph
answers.C: 20 mph
answers.D: 15 mph

correct_answer: 25 mph
why_correct: State driving laws allow up to 15 mph faster than main-line traffic, not to exceed 35 mph. At 10 mph, the maximum is 25 mph.

why_incorrect.B: Although below the 35 mph cap, it would exceed the +15 mph limit over 10 mph traffic.
why_incorrect.C: 20 mph is permitted but not the maximum in this scenario.
why_incorrect.D: 15 mph is permitted but not the maximum; up to 25 mph is allowed.

question: Which of the following are exceptions to the requirement to drive on the right half of the roadway in Minnesota?

answers.A: When overtaking or passing another vehicle where passing is permitted
answers.B: When the right half is closed to traffic due to construction or repair
answers.C: When the roadway is divided into three marked lanes
answers.D: All of the above

correct_answer: All of the above
why_correct: Minnesota law lists passing (where permitted), right-half closure due to construction/repair, and three marked lanes as exceptions to the keep-right rule.

why_incorrect.A: This is one valid exception, but it is not the only one listed.
why_incorrect.B: This is also a valid exception, but not the only one.
why_incorrect.C: This is another valid exception, but there are additional exceptions as well.

question: Under Minnesota state driving laws, what is prohibited regarding wireless communications while driving?

answers.A: Using a wireless communications device to compose, read, or send electronic messages while driving
answers.B: Any use of a wireless device, including voice calls, at any time while driving
answers.C: Using GPS navigation on a wireless device at any time
answers.D: Listening to music streamed from a wireless device while driving

why_correct: State driving laws prohibit using a wireless communications device to compose, read, or send electronic messages while driving; electronic messages include e-mails and text messages.

why_incorrect.B: The cited portion of state driving laws specifically bans composing/reading/sending electronic messages; it does not state that all wireless uses (such as voice calls) are universally prohibited.
why_incorrect.C: State driving laws' prohibition applies to electronic messaging; GPS navigation is not identified in this section as prohibited.
why_incorrect.D: Streaming or listening to music via a wireless device is not listed in the cited prohibition against composing, reading, or sending electronic messages in state driving laws.

question: What is an appropriate way to warn other drivers about a crash scene?

answers.A: Activate emergency warning lights and set out flares or use a flashlight
answers.B: Stand in the lane and wave traffic around the vehicles
answers.C: Place small rocks behind your tires
answers.D: Rely solely on your horn to alert approaching drivers

why_correct: State driving laws recommend using emergency warning lights, flares, or a flashlight to warn other drivers of danger.

why_incorrect.B: Standing in traffic is unsafe and not advised.
why_incorrect.C: This is ineffective for warning approaching drivers.
why_incorrect.D: A horn alone is not an adequate method to secure the crash scene.

question: If you damage property other than a vehicle (e.g., a fence or mailbox), what must you do?

answers.A: Notify law enforcement only; contacting the owner is not necessary
answers.B: Inform the property owner
answers.C: Leave the scene if there are no witnesses
answers.D: Wait for the property owner to contact you later

correct_answer: Inform the property owner
why_correct: State driving laws require you to inform the property owner if you damage property other than a vehicle.

why_incorrect.A: Notifying law enforcement alone doesn’t satisfy the requirement to inform the owner.
why_incorrect.C: Leaving without informing the owner fails to meet the legal requirement.
why_incorrect.D: You must proactively inform the owner; waiting is not sufficient.

question: Why is it especially dangerous to “cut off” a commercial bus or truck by moving in quickly from either side, according to state driving laws?

answers.A: Because they have large blind spots and require more distance to stop
answers.B: Because commercial drivers are not allowed to use their brakes suddenly
answers.C: Because commercial vehicles always travel at higher speeds than cars
answers.D: Because commercial vehicles must always yield to smaller vehicles

why_correct: State driving laws explain that large commercial vehicles have significant blind spots and need much more distance to stop, so cutting in quickly can prevent the driver from seeing you or stopping in time.

why_incorrect.B: Commercial drivers can and do use brakes; the issue is the greater stopping distance required, not an inability to brake.
why_incorrect.C: Commercial vehicles do not always travel at higher speeds; the danger cited is their blind spots and longer stopping distances.
why_incorrect.D: There is no rule that commercial vehicles must always yield to smaller vehicles; yielding depends on the situation and right-of-way rules.

question: How does wind turbulence between two vehicles traveling in opposite directions typically affect them?

answers.A: It pulls the vehicles toward each other
answers.B: It pushes the vehicles away from each other
answers.C: It has no noticeable effect
answers.D: It always causes vehicles to lose control

why_correct: State driving laws note that turbulence between two vehicles will push them away from each other, which is why staying to the right reduces the chance of a sideswipe.

why_incorrect.A: Turbulence does not pull vehicles together; it tends to push them apart.
why_incorrect.C: Turbulence can affect vehicle stability and position, so it is noticeable and important to account for.
why_incorrect.D: While turbulence can affect stability, it does not always cause a loss of control if drivers respond properly.

question: When turning left or making a U-turn to the left, what does state law require you to do at an intersection?

answers.A: Always proceed immediately when the traffic signal is yellow
answers.B: Yield the right-of-way to opposing vehicles that are so close as to constitute an immediate hazard
answers.C: You have the right-of-way over oncoming traffic during your turn
answers.D: Make the turn without signalling if no other vehicles are visible

why_correct: State driving laws require vehicles turning left or making a left U-turn to yield the right-of-way to oncoming vehicles that are close enough to constitute an immediate hazard.

why_incorrect.A: A yellow light is a caution signal; you should not always proceed immediately and must still yield when required.
why_incorrect.C: Left-turning drivers must yield to oncoming traffic when it constitutes an immediate hazard; they do not automatically have right-of-way.
why_incorrect.D: You must signal required turns and cannot omit signaling just because no vehicles are visible.

question: Under state driving laws, which situation allows you to drive left of the centerline instead of staying on the right half?

answers.A: When overtaking or passing another vehicle where passing is permitted
answers.B: When the right half of the roadway is closed due to construction or repair
answers.C: When necessary to comply with the move over law for an authorized vehicle stopped on the roadway
answers.D: All of the above

correct_answer: All of the above
why_correct: State driving laws list these as exceptions to the requirement to drive on the right half of the roadway.

why_incorrect.A: Passing in a permitted zone is one valid exception, but it is not the only one.
why_incorrect.B: A closure of the right half for construction is another exception, but not the only one.
why_incorrect.C: Moving over for an authorized stopped vehicle is an exception, but it is not the only one.

question: Which of the following may be offered as an alternative in some cases instead of contesting a citation through formal court proceedings under state driving laws?

answers.A: Mandatory license suspension without hearing
answers.B: A diversion program such as driver education training
answers.C: Immediate vehicle forfeiture
answers.D: Public shaming on the agency's website

why_correct: State driving laws note that diversion programs, for example driver education training, may be an option in some cases as an alternative to traditional court proceedings.

why_incorrect.A: Mandatory suspension without a hearing is not presented as an alternative; drivers have legal rights and potential alternatives.
why_incorrect.C: Immediate vehicle forfeiture is not described as a common diversion alternative.
why_incorrect.D: Public shaming is not a lawful alternative provided by the legal process for citations.

question: What is a likely legal consequence for disobeying a flag person's directions or the posted speed limit in a highway work zone?

answers.A: A verbal warning with no further action
answers.B: A violation and a financial penalty
answers.C: Immediate suspension of your driver’s license
answers.D: A requirement to do community service at the site

why_correct: State driving laws specify that failing to obey a flag person or disobeying the speed limit in a work zone will result in a violation and a financial penalty.

why_incorrect.A: While a warning might occur in some situations, the law specifically allows penalties for violations, not just verbal warnings.
why_incorrect.C: License suspension is not the typical immediate consequence for these violations; financial penalties are standard.
why_incorrect.D: Community service at the site is not the standard statutory penalty for these work zone violations.

question: When making the initial right turn from the side street at a J-turn, what lane movement is allowed to minimize time in the through lanes?

answers.A: You must enter the nearest lane only and remain there until the next intersection
answers.B: You may cross both lanes and move directly into the left-turn lane in one motion when it is safe to do so
answers.C: You must stop on the shoulder before moving into the left-turn lane
answers.D: You may drive in the median to reach the left-turn lane faster

correct_answer: You may cross both lanes and move directly into the left-turn lane in one motion when it is safe to do so
why_correct: State driving laws allow crossing both lanes in one safe motion to enter the left-turn lane.

why_incorrect.A: The law permits moving across both lanes in a single safe motion.
why_incorrect.C: Stopping on the shoulder is not required or indicated.
why_incorrect.D: Driving in the median (outside the opening) is not permitted.

question: According to state driving laws, what do white road signs indicate?

answers.A: Construction or maintenance warnings
answers.B: Motorist services like gas, food, or lodging
answers.C: Recreation and cultural interest areas
answers.D: Regulatory information (they regulate)

correct_answer: Regulatory information (they regulate)
why_correct: State driving laws state that white signs are regulatory and communicate rules of the road.

why_incorrect.A: Construction warnings are not conveyed by white regulatory signs.
why_incorrect.B: Services information is not the purpose of white regulatory signs.
why_incorrect.C: Recreation or cultural interest is not the meaning of white regulatory signs.

question: What is the minimum distance before a turn that you must signal your intent?

answers.A: 50 feet
answers.B: 75 feet
answers.C: 100 feet
answers.D: Only while you are turning

correct_answer: 100 feet
why_correct: The rule states you must signal your intent at least 100 feet before the turn.

why_incorrect.A: 50 feet is less than the required minimum distance.
why_incorrect.B: 75 feet does not meet the minimum requirement.
why_incorrect.D: You must signal before the turn, not only during it.

question: When you follow a commercial vehicle at night, what should you do to avoid blinding the driver?

answers.A: Use high beams at all times
answers.B: Dim your headlights
answers.C: Flash your headlights continuously
answers.D: Turn off your headlights when close behind the truck

why_correct: State driving laws state that commercial vehicles have large side mirrors that can reflect light, so you should dim your headlights at night to avoid blinding the driver.

why_incorrect.A: High beams can reflect in the truck's mirrors and blind the driver—opposite of safe practice.
why_incorrect.C: Flashing headlights can startle or confuse other drivers and is not the recommended action in state driving laws.
why_incorrect.D: Turning off headlights is illegal and unsafe; dimming is the correct measure.

question: According to state driving laws, where is it illegal to throw, leave, place, or dump items like cigarettes, glass, nails, trash, or snow?

answers.A: On streets, roadways, and public land
answers.B: On private land without the owner’s consent
answers.C: Both A and B
answers.D: Only on highways outside city limits

why_correct: State driving laws prohibit discarding such items on streets, roadways, and public land, and also on private land without the owner’s consent.

why_incorrect.A: This is true but incomplete; private land without consent is also prohibited.
why_incorrect.B: This is true but incomplete; public areas are also prohibited.
why_incorrect.D: Incorrect; the prohibition is not limited to highways or specific locations.

question: The Move Over Law also applies when approaching which of the following stopped or parked vehicles according to state driving laws?

answers.A: Stalled or disabled vehicles
answers.B: Service patrol, road maintenance, utility, and construction vehicles
answers.C: Parked emergency vehicles such as tow trucks or ambulances with flashing lights
answers.D: All of the above

why_correct: State driving laws extend the Move Over Law to stalled or disabled vehicles and parked service, maintenance, utility, construction, and emergency vehicles with flashing lights—all require moving over or slowing and passing with caution.

why_incorrect.A: Stalled or disabled vehicles are covered, but this option omits other covered vehicle types.
why_incorrect.B: Service and maintenance vehicles are covered, but this option omits other covered vehicle types.
why_incorrect.C: Parked emergency vehicles with lights are covered, but this option omits other covered vehicle types.

question: When making a left turn, when must you yield to approaching vehicles according to state driving laws?

answers.A: Only if the approaching vehicle has its headlights on
answers.B: Only if the approaching vehicle is signaling to turn
answers.C: When the approaching vehicles are in the intersection or are near enough to pose a risk of a crash
answers.D: You never have to yield if you have started your turn

why_correct: State driving laws require a driver making a left turn to yield to oncoming vehicles that are in the intersection or close enough to create a risk of a crash.

why_incorrect.A: Incorrect — headlights are irrelevant; proximity and risk of collision determine yielding.
why_incorrect.B: Incorrect — whether the approaching vehicle is signaling is not the sole factor; you must yield if they are in the intersection or close enough to be hazardous.
why_incorrect.D: Incorrect — even if you begin a turn, you must yield to oncoming traffic that is in the intersection or close enough to be dangerous.

question: Where should you position your vehicle when waiting to make a left turn at a green light with oncoming traffic?

answers.A: Remain behind the stop line and do not enter the intersection
answers.B: Enter the intersection so your body appears even with the curb line of the street you’re turning into
answers.C: Move partially into the oncoming lane to shorten the turn
answers.D: Stop past the crosswalk in the middle of the intersection

correct_answer: Enter the intersection so your body appears even with the curb line of the street you’re turning into
why_correct: State driving laws advise positioning into the intersection with your body aligned with the curb line, which sets up a safe, legal left turn when a gap appears or the light changes.

why_incorrect.A: Staying behind the stop line may prevent you from completing the turn when safe or when the light changes.
why_incorrect.C: Entering the oncoming lane is illegal and dangerous.
why_incorrect.D: Stopping past the crosswalk or improperly in the intersection is unsafe and can block traffic.

question: Flashing yellow lights on a school bus will be activated at least how many feet before it stops in a speed zone of 35 mph or less, according to state driving laws?

answers.A: 50 feet
answers.B: 100 feet
answers.C: 200 feet
answers.D: 300 feet

why_correct: State driving laws specify that flashing yellow lights are activated at least 100 feet before a bus stops in speed zones of 35 mph or less.

why_incorrect.A: 50 feet is too short; the law requires at least 100 feet in lower speed zones.
why_incorrect.C: 200 feet exceeds the minimum specified for speed zones of 35 mph or less.
why_incorrect.D: 300 feet is the minimum for speed zones over 35 mph, not for 35 mph or less.

question: What is the primary purpose of the three-second rule?

answers.A: To ensure a safe following distance under normal driving conditions
answers.B: To determine the minimum stopping distance at 55 mph
answers.C: To calculate how long it takes to clear an intersection
answers.D: To set the legal distance required to pass a vehicle

correct_answer: To ensure a safe following distance under normal driving conditions
why_correct: State driving laws use the three-second rule to help drivers maintain a minimum following interval in normal conditions, increasing the gap when conditions worsen.

why_incorrect.B: Stopping distance varies with speed, vehicle, and conditions; the rule addresses following interval, not a fixed stopping distance.
why_incorrect.C: Intersection clearing time is not what the three-second rule measures.
why_incorrect.D: Passing distance laws are separate from following distance guidance.

question: According to state driving laws, what is the recommended practice regarding pets in vehicles during temperature extremes?

answers.A: Leave pets in the car with windows cracked on hot days
answers.B: It’s safe to leave pets in the car briefly if parked in the shade
answers.C: Pets should not be left unattended in vehicles, especially on very hot or very cold days
answers.D: Leave pets in the car as long as they have water

correct_answer: Pets should not be left unattended in vehicles, especially on very hot or very cold days
why_correct: State driving laws warn that temperature extremes are very dangerous to animals and advise that pets should not be left in vehicles, especially during very hot or cold weather.

why_incorrect.A: Cracking windows does not prevent dangerous heat buildup; state driving laws caution against leaving pets in hot conditions.
why_incorrect.B: Parking in the shade does not eliminate risk; state driving laws advise not to leave pets unattended during temperature extremes.
why_incorrect.D: Providing water does not mitigate the dangers of extreme temperatures noted in state driving laws.

question: Which of the following is an exception that allows you to use a wireless communications device while your vehicle is in motion or part of traffic?

answers.A: To report a crash or crime
answers.B: To check social media while stopped at a red light
answers.C: To type an address into GPS while moving
answers.D: To read a message in slow-moving traffic

correct_answer: To report a crash or crime
why_correct: Exceptions include using the device to obtain emergency assistance or to report a crash or crime, and when the device is solely voice-activated or in hands-free mode.

why_incorrect.B: Being stopped at a light still counts as being part of traffic; social media use is not an exception.
why_incorrect.C: Manual input while moving is not permitted under the rule.
why_incorrect.D: Slow traffic is still traffic; reading messages is prohibited unless solely voice-activated or hands-free.

question: If you are on a multilane road and are closer to the left shoulder when an officer signals you to stop, what does state driving laws say you should do?

answers.A: Move to the left shoulder if there is a full lane to park
answers.B: Cross multiple lanes to reach the right shoulder immediately
answers.C: Stop in the traffic lane and wait for the officer
answers.D: Make a U-turn to reach the right shoulder

why_correct: State driving laws allow pulling to the left shoulder on a multilane road when you are closer to it, provided there is a full lane available to park safely.

why_incorrect.B: Crossing multiple lanes can be unsafe and is not the specified action.
why_incorrect.C: Stopping in the traffic lane is to be avoided if a shoulder or full lane is available.
why_incorrect.D: Making a U-turn during a traffic stop is unsafe and not permitted by the procedure.

question: When warning lights or gates are activated at a railroad crossing, what must you do?

answers.A: Stop at least 10 feet from the nearest rail or gate
answers.B: Stop at least 5 feet from the nearest rail or gate
answers.C: Slow down and proceed if you think no train is coming
answers.D: Stop only if you can see the train approaching

correct_answer: Stop at least 10 feet from the nearest rail or gate
why_correct: State driving laws require you to stop your vehicle at least 10 feet from the nearest rail or gate when warning lights or gates are activated.

why_incorrect.B: Five feet is not sufficient; the law specifies a minimum of 10 feet.
why_incorrect.C: You must stop when devices are activated; you cannot proceed based on your judgment alone.
why_incorrect.D: Activation of lights or gates requires a stop regardless of whether you see the train.

question: On a highway with more than one lane traveling in the same direction, where should you generally drive?

answers.A: In the left-most lane to keep up with faster traffic
answers.B: In the center lane to avoid merging vehicles
answers.C: In the right-hand lane when available
answers.D: In any lane; there is no general rule

correct_answer: In the right-hand lane when available
why_correct: Drivers should use the right-hand lane when available on multi-lane roads traveling in the same direction.

why_incorrect.A: The left-most lane is not for general travel; it should be vacated to allow passing when practical.
why_incorrect.B: There is no rule favoring the center lane over the right; the general rule is to use the right-hand lane.
why_incorrect.D: There is a general rule: drive in the right-hand lane when available.

question: Before turning on a red light, to whom must you yield?

answers.A: Only vehicles already in the intersection
answers.B: Only pedestrians in the crosswalk to your right
answers.C: All pedestrians and traffic with the right-of-way
answers.D: No one, if your path looks clear

correct_answer: All pedestrians and traffic with the right-of-way
why_correct: State driving laws require you to yield to traffic and pedestrians before turning on red.

why_incorrect.A: You must yield not just to vehicles in the intersection but to all traffic with the right-of-way.
why_incorrect.B: You must yield to all pedestrians, not only those to your right.
why_incorrect.D: You must yield even if the path appears clear.

question: When should you reduce your speed for a turn according to state driving laws?

answers.A: Before making the turn
answers.B: During the turn
answers.C: After completing the turn
answers.D: Only if pedestrians are present

correct_answer: Before making the turn
why_correct: State driving laws advise slowing down before making turns to maintain control and safety.

why_incorrect.B: Slowing during the turn can lead to poor control and is not recommended.
why_incorrect.C: Waiting until after the turn defeats the purpose of safe speed adjustment.
why_incorrect.D: You should slow before every turn, not only when pedestrians are present.

question: How should you treat a flashing red traffic light at an intersection under state driving laws?

answers.A: As a warning to slow down but proceed if clear
answers.B: As an all-way stop control (treat like a stop sign)
answers.C: As a yield sign
answers.D: As a malfunctioning signal; ignore it and follow usual right-of-way rules

why_correct: State driving laws treat flashing red traffic lights as all-way stop controls, meaning drivers must stop and follow the same yielding rules as at all-way stop signs.

why_incorrect.A: Incorrect — flashing red requires a stop, not just slowing down.
why_incorrect.C: Incorrect — a flashing red is not a yield; it requires a full stop and then yielding as at an all-way stop.
why_incorrect.D: Incorrect — you must stop and follow the all-way stop procedure rather than ignoring the signal.

question: Under state driving laws, which of the following is an allowable reason for a bicyclist to enter or cross an intersection against a red traffic signal?

answers.A: The traffic-control signal continues to show a red light for an unreasonable time
answers.B: The traffic-control signal appears to be malfunctioning or has failed to detect the bicycle
answers.C: No vehicle or person is approaching on the roadway to be crossed or those approaching are so far away that they do not constitute an immediate hazard
answers.D: All of the above

why_correct: State driving laws list all of these conditions as circumstances in which a bicyclist may enter or cross against a red light.

why_incorrect.A: While a signal stuck on red is a valid reason, it is only one of several listed reasons.
why_incorrect.B: A malfunction or failure to detect the bicycle is valid, but not the sole condition.
why_incorrect.C: Safe gaps in traffic are a valid reason, but there are additional permitted reasons as well.

question: Is it permissible under state driving laws to ignore a school bus flagger's stop signal if you do not see any children present?

answers.A: Yes — if no children are visible, you may proceed
answers.B: No — you must not proceed until directed by the flagger or a police officer
answers.C: Yes — but only if the bus driver motions you to go
answers.D: Only if a police officer is not present

why_correct: State driving laws require drivers stopped by a school bus flagger to remain stopped until directed to proceed by the flagger or a police officer, regardless of whether children are visible.

why_incorrect.A: Visibility of children does not change the requirement under state driving laws to wait for the flagger or officer.
why_incorrect.C: The bus driver’s motion is not a substitute for direction from the flagger or a police officer under state driving laws.
why_incorrect.D: The absence of a police officer does not authorize ignoring the flagger; the flagger's direction is sufficient and controlling.

question: Which is a valid reason for a bicyclist to move toward the center of the lane under state driving laws?

answers.A: To avoid hazards such as rough surfaces, debris, drainage grates, or a narrow traffic lane
answers.B: When overtaking or passing another vehicle
answers.C: When preparing to make a left turn
answers.D: All of the above

correct_answer: All of the above
why_correct: State driving laws allow bicyclists to move toward the center of the lane to avoid hazards, when passing, and when making a left turn.

why_incorrect.A: Avoiding hazards is a valid reason, but it is not the only one.
why_incorrect.B: Passing is a valid reason, but there are others as well.
why_incorrect.C: Left turns are a valid reason, but not the only one.

question: On a two-lane road with traffic in both directions, on which side may you pass another vehicle when passing is permitted?

answers.A: On the left side of the vehicle ahead
answers.B: On the right side on the shoulder
answers.C: On either side, as long as you signal
answers.D: Directly between lanes without fully changing lanes

correct_answer: On the left side of the vehicle ahead
why_correct: State driving laws specify that when passing is permitted on two-lane roads with opposing traffic, you pass on the left side of the vehicle ahead.

why_incorrect.B: Using the shoulder to pass is not permitted by state driving laws.
why_incorrect.C: Passing on the right is not the standard method on two-lane, two-way roads and is not what the law authorizes here.
why_incorrect.D: Straddling lanes is unsafe and not a lawful passing method.

question: Which vehicle manufacturing date is exempt from seat belt requirements under state driving laws?

answers.A: Before January 1, 1965
answers.B: Before January 1, 1970
answers.C: Before January 1, 1960
answers.D: Before January 1, 1985
